title: Cortisone injections used by sports stars ‘may cause joints to disintegrate’
text:
Cortisone injections may be more harmful than we realised (Picture: iStockphoto; SWNS)

Athletes may suffer devastating long term effects from cortisone injections, a new study has warned.

The treatment has longed been used as a short term measure to help sports stars perform through the pain barrier but the drug may ultimately cause joints to disintegrate.

Doctors inject anti-inflammatory corticosteroids directly into the hip and knee joints to treat osteoarthritic pain.

The procedure is generally viewed as safe, with patients made to sign a consent form, which largely warns of side-effects common with most injections.

But Study leader Dr Ali Guermazi and his team at Boston University School of Medicine argue consent forms should now be altered to mention the risk of rapid, progressive arthritis and stress fractures.

He said: ‘We’ve been telling patients that even if these injections don’t relieve your pain, they’re not going to hurt you.

‘But now we suspect that this is not necessarily the case.’

Sports stars use injections to play through pain (Picture: iStockphoto)

Dr Guermazi added: ‘Physicians do not commonly tell patients about the possibility of joint collapse or subchondral insufficiency fractures that may lead to earlier total hip or knee replacement.

The researchers singled out patients receiving shots with little sign of osteoarthritis on an X-ray as being at greater risk of destructive arthritis after injections.

They recommended these patients were carefully monitored – especially when the pain they experience is disproportionate to what’s visible on the scan.

Doctors should also reconsider administering cortisone jabs when a patient’s pain has changed acutely in a way that’s unexplained on an X-ray – as they could be suffering from an underlying condition affecting joint health, the study added.

X-ray of man, 53, who returned with worsening hip pain after cortisone injections (Picture: SWNS)

Younger patients were also a big concern to the team and they advised they should be told of the potential consequences of an injection before they were given it.

Dr Guermazi warned sport stars of the potential dangers in using the injections, saying: ‘Intra-articular joint injection of steroids is a very common treatment for osteoarthritis-related pain, but potential aggravation of pre-existing conditions or actual side effects in a subset of patients need to be explored further to better understand the risks associated with it.

‘What we wanted to do with our paper is to tell physicians and patients to be careful, because these injections are likely not as safe as we thought.’
